lines.text: Take two men. Say they have robbed and lied, and have never paid. The man whom one of them has robbed comes to me and says, "Kill that man who's robbed me." And I kill him. The other man becomes ill and would die, except for a physician who returns him to health to rob and lie again. Who's the villain in this piece? Me or the physician?
Judges interest me. They have the power of life and death. So do physicians.
I like you, Physician. You're like me. You and I may well be the only two honest men in town.
Don't compare us. We've got nothing in common.
Everybody dies.
Why do you want to kill me, friend?
You know why.
All right. If you think you can do it, go ahead and try. My hands are on the table. I couldn't possibly outdraw you. So go ahead and shoot.
A lot of people would like to kill John Gant. But it took a healer with a hammer to make it easy for them.

I'll stay here until I'm ready to leave. I use my gun for money, and I don't like to work for nothing. But you trouble me again, and I might have to break my rule. That's my prescription, physician. You'd better get it filled.
I don't suppose you know why he's locked himself in his office, do you?
He's afraid of me.
You were expecting that to happen, weren't you?
I wasn't surprised.
You killed him.
You're wrong, Physician. He started killing himself long before I ever got here.
Why didn't you kill me?
I wasn't paid to.
Viciousness in men, Luke, is inside. Deep inside.
But why? What caused it? I keep wanting to know what makes him tick.

Well, it's usually a kind of logical progression. A youngster starts running with a gang. Sooner or later they're killed off or sent to prison until he's the only one left. He's gotten away with killing and he keeps going with it... alone. He can't let himself even like someone because some day he might have to kill them. By then there's no turning back. Even if he wants to throw his gun away, he can't because he knows that just around the bend there's someone that will kill him.
[last lines]
Gant... I could take a look at that arm.
Don't worry about it, Physician. Everything comes to a finish.
Sam must hate us even more than I thought. He's going to let us stay together.
